title: san serif with a loopy edge
content:
Hello folks!

what is this font?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230331im_/http:/typophile.com/files/larcobaleno_syllables_4798.png)
author: mercer

comments.content:
According to [their website](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230331/http:/www.larcobaleno.com/), they use '205 Maax Medium LAB' ('LAB' standing for L'ArcoBaleno) which happens to be a custom version (how much?) of [Maax](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230331/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/gautier/maax) 205 by Damien Gautier. The main difference is /a which looks to be a mix between of the top of regular / [a](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230331/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/gautier/maax/medium/glyphs.html?render=old#glyphs/556267/93) and bottom of [alternate](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230331/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/gautier/maax/medium/glyphs.html?render=old#glyphs/556267/426).

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230331im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Untitled-1_4102.png)
Are there free fonts similar to Maax? with the loopy edges of a

Can't name one without thinking actually but try having a look to [Google Fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230331/http:/typophile.com/wiki/https%3A/%252Fwww.google.com/fonts) directory and [Font Squirrel](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230331/http:/www.fontsquirrel.com/), 2 trust-worthy free fonts providers.
